caption_original: Canadian Wildlife Service Species at Risk biologist, Dr. Wellicome, trains a field technician to use a scope to view the underground nest of a Burrowing Owl. The scope feeds live infrared video to a pair of goggles, allowing the user to count how many adult owls, owlets, eggs, and cached prey are inside the burrow. Using a hood helps block out daylight glare to get a clearer image in the gOWLggles.: Danielle Todd...

caption_original: It’s Arctic Science Month! Cheryl is a wildlife scientist here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Together with her team, Indigenous knowledge and innovative research techniques are combined to understand how changing snow and ice conditions – driven by climate change – affect the habitat of the Peary Caribou, which lives in the high arctic, and is considered endangered in Canada. ...

caption_original: David Phillips, senior meteorologist at Environment and Climate Change Canada, calls “the year of too much” – the weather across the country was either too dry, too hot, or too wet. He’s compiled his annual list of the Top Ten Weather Stories in Canada during . His list includes everything from catastrophic wildfires in British Columbia to severe winter storms in the Atlantic provinces. “The increased severity of our weather is certainly consistent with our eectations of rising global temperatures,” Phillips says. “This list demonstrates that our communities must become more resilient to the effects of climate change.”...

caption_original: Guess what? We built two “supersites” in Iqaluit and Whitehorse! A supersite has a variety of weather instruments that allow scientists to measure atmospheric conditions in detail. For people living in the North, information like the temperature and humidity isn’t as important as they are in the South. Knowing about blowing snow and ice-fog (a fog made up of small ice crystals suspended in the air!) are much more relevant! The new sites will help us understand what weather instruments will work best, so that we can improve weather forecasts in the North....

caption_original: Julie and a number of Canadian Wildlife Service biologists from our Sackville, New Brunswick office were in the field last week helping out with the annual Cape Tormentine Christmas Bird Count. The annual Count is one of the largest citizen science projects in North America; the results help provide information about the status of bird populations. These brave employees faced brisk arctic-like winds to record different species! :Garry Donaldson...

caption_original: Do you remember me? Back in April, we held a contest to give me a name! I am a Common Loon and the mascot of the Canadian Wildlife Service here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. You suggested lots of great names. I chose “Kwimu,” which means “spirit bird” in many Indigenous languages. Since the name “Tuuli” was also very popular, I decided to give this name to the chick that I carry on my back. Tuuli means loon in Inuktitut. Thanks for participating! ...
